data: The inscription runs under the upper edge of the tile.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

Massimo Cultraro, ‘Funzione e Destinazione Delle Tegole Con Iscrizioni Anelleniche: Nuovi e Vecchi Dati Dal Mendolito Di Adrano (Catania)’, Studi Etruschi LXX–MMIV, no. 3 (2005): 227–51

The inscription has been interpreted by all editors as an onomastic formula. It is on a fragment of a tile found in 
                    contrada Mendolito together with another one apparently written by the same hand. The two documents were initially 
                    interpreted as two funerary inscriptions (Manganaro 1961b, 110), then as a single votive inscription dedicated by magistrates 
                    to deities (Pisani 1964, 127; Whatmough 1968, 576-577; Ribezzo 1923, 224) and more recently (Cultraro 2005) as a single 
                    inscription on the roofing slabs of a building (a house, or more likely a 'public' building) that would bear the dedication of a member 
                    of the community financing the structure.
                    Whether these are parts of the same inscription is, however, difficult to prove due to the lack of specific details on the archaeological 
                    context and a connection - if not palaeographic - between this inscription and the other one, that bears a formula interpreted as 
                    'gift of' + the name of the donor. 
                    The alphabet is the typical one of Sikel inscriptions from the Etna area. Worthy of note, in particular, is the presence of the arrow-shaped alpha, the digamma 
                    (with value of v, see also ).

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Manganaro 1961

translation

Reses Anires.

commentary

The inscription has been interpreted by all editors as an onomastic formula. It is on a fragment of a tile found in contrada Mendolito together with another one apparently written by the same hand. The two documents were initially interpreted as two funerary inscriptions (Manganaro 1961b, 110), then as a single votive inscription dedicated by magistrates to deities (Pisani 1964, 127; Whatmough 1968, 576-577; Ribezzo 1923, 224) and more recently (Cultraro 2005) as a single inscription on the roofing slabs of a building (a house, or more likely a 'public' building) that would bear the dedication of a member of the community financing the structure. Whether these are parts of the same inscription is, however, difficult to prove due to the lack of specific details on the archaeological context and a connection - if not palaeographic - between this inscription and the other one, that bears a formula interpreted as 'gift of' + the name of the donor. The alphabet is the typical one of Sikel inscriptions from the Etna area. Worthy of note, in particular, is the presence of the arrow-shaped alpha, the digamma (with value of v, see also ISic003364).

commentary

The inscription has been interpreted by all editors as an onomastic formula. It is on a fragment of a tile found in contrada Mendolito together with another one apparently written by the same hand. The two documents were initially interpreted as two funerary inscriptions (Manganaro 1961b, 110), then as a single votive inscription dedicated by magistrates to deities (Pisani 1964, 127; Whatmough 1968, 576-577; Ribezzo 1923, 224) and more recently (Cultraro 2005) as a single inscription on the roofing slabs of a building (a house, or more likely a 'public' building) that would bear the dedication of a member of the community financing the structure. Whether these are parts of the same inscription is, however, difficult to prove due to the lack of specific details on the archaeological context and a connection - if not palaeographic - between this inscription and the other one, that bears a formula interpreted as 'gift of' + the name of the donor. The alphabet is the typical one of Sikel inscriptions from the Etna area. Worthy of note, in particular, is the presence of the arrow-shaped alpha, the digamma (with value of v, see also ISic003364).
